choices.text: Immediate myringotomy with grommet insertion
Empirical antibiotic therapy for 5 days
Start medical treatment with decongestants and encourage Valsalva manoeuvre
Cortical mastoidectomy and tympanotomy

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought by his parents with complaints of poor attention in class and delayed speech development. There is no pain or fever. Otoscopy reveals a dull, retracted tympanic membrane with visible air bubbles behind it. Audiometry shows a conductive hearing loss of around 30 dB. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start medical treatment with decongestants and encourage Valsalva manoeuvre

 

The child presents with Otitis Media with Effusion (OME), also known as serous/secretory otitis media or glue ear, a non-purulent effusion in the middle ear without signs of acute infection.

 

Key Clinical Clues:

  • Age group: 5–8 years
  • Symptoms: Hearing loss, delayed speech, no pain or fever
  • Otoscopy: Dull, retracted TM, possible air-fluid level
  • Audiometry: Conductive loss (20–40 dB)
  • Impedance audiometry: Flat curve with reduced compliance
  • Cause: ET dysfunction, adenoid hypertrophy, allergy, unresolved AOM

 

Treatment Strategy:

 

  1. Initial medical management:
    • Topical/systemic decongestants
    • Antihistamines/steroids if allergic component
    • Antibiotics only if URI present
    • Middle ear aeration: Valsalva, politzerization, chewing gum in children
  2. Surgical intervention:
    • Myringotomy with fluid aspiration if conservative treatment fails
    • Grommet insertion for persistent/recurrent cases
    • Adenoidectomy/tonsillectomy if anatomical obstruction exists
  3. Cortical mastoidectomy/tympanotomy: Reserved for loculated effusion, cholesterol granuloma, or failed previous interventions

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Immediate myringotomy with grommet insertion: Too early — grommet is reserved for persistent or recurrent cases, not first-line

 

Option B. Empirical antibiotic therapy for 5 days: Antibiotics are not primary treatment unless secondary infection is suspected

 

Option D. Cortical mastoidectomy and tympanotomy: Cortical mastoidectomy. is not indicated at this stage; it's for complicated or resistant cases

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otitis media with effusion in children is managed initially with decongestants, antiallergics, and maneuvers to ventilate the middle ear; surgery is considered if medical management fails.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 65

choices.text: Acquired cholesteatoma
Otitis media with effusion
Congenital cholesteatoma
Tympanosclerosis

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought for a school health check-up. Otoscopic examination reveals a pearly white mass visible behind an intact tympanic membrane, and the child has mild conductive hearing loss. There is no history of ear discharge or previous ear infection. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Congenital cholesteatoma

 

Congenital cholesteatoma is characterized by the presence of squamous epithelium-derived keratin debris in the middle ear cleft, arising from epidermal cell rests left behind during embryogenesis.

 

Key Features of Congenital Cholesteatoma:

 

  • Location: Middle ear, petrous apex, cerebellopontine angle
  • Presentation in middle ear:
    • Appears as a white, pearly mass behind an intact tympanic membrane
    • Causes conductive hearing loss
    • Often found incidentally or during myringotomy
  • Can rupture, leading to symptoms similar to CSOM

 

 

Typically seen in anterosuperior quadrant as a cotton wool mass.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acquired cholesteatoma: Requires TM perforation or retraction pocket; not present here

 

 

Option B. Otitis media with effusion: Presents with dull TM and fluid levels, not a white mass.

 

 

Option D. Tympanosclerosis: Appears as chalky white patches due to calcification, not as a mass

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital cholesteatoma presents as a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane and causes conductive hearing loss, commonly discovered incidentally in children.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 67

choices.text: Postauricular abscess
Bezold abscess
Zygomatic abscess
Luc abscess

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a history of chronic ear discharge, high-grade fever, torticollis, and a tender swelling in the upper part of the neck deep to the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The clinician suspects an abscess arising due to mastoid disease tracking through the mastoid tip. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bezold abscess

 

It results from pus breaking through the medial wall of the mastoid tip, presenting as neck swelling, usually deep to sternocleidomastoid, sometimes extending into parapharyngeal space. Associated signs include torticollis, fever, and history of otorrhoea.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Postauricular abscess: Incorrect. This is the most common abscess in mastoiditis but presents behind the ear with pinna pushed forward, outward, and downward, not with neck swelling.

Option C. Zygomatic abscess: Incorrect. Occurs due to infection of zygomatic air cells, with swelling in front of and above the pinna, and eyelid edema, not neck swelling.

 

Option D. Luc abscess: Incorrect. Also called meatal abscess, caused by pus breaking into the bony external auditory canal, presenting as deep canal swelling, not in the neck.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bezold abscess is a deep neck abscess secondary to mastoiditis, characterized by pus tracking from the mastoid tip into the neck, presenting with neck swelling, torticollis, and systemic signs.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 78

choices.text: Canal wall up procedure has a lower rate of residual disease and does not require a second-look surgery
Canal wall down procedure provides a normal meatal appearance and allows unrestricted swimming
Canal wall up procedure preserves a normal meatus and is better suited for patients requiring hearing aids
Canal wall down procedure requires second-look surgery to rule out cholesteatoma recurrence

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the comparison between canal wall up and canal wall down mastoidectomy procedures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Canal wall up procedure preserves a normal meatus and is better suited for patients requiring hearing aids

 

  • Canal wall up procedure preserves the normal appearance of the external canal (meatus) and makes wearing hearing aids easier, which is important for auditory rehabilitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Canal wall up procedure has a lower rate of residual disease and does not require a second-look surgery: Incorrect. Canal wall up procedure actually has a higher rate of recurrent or residual cholesteatoma and hence typically requires a second-look surgery after 6 months.

 

Option B. Canal wall down procedure provides a normal meatal appearance and allows unrestricted swimming: Incorrect. Canal wall down procedure results in a widely open meatus, but swimming is generally restricted due to risk of mastoid cavity infections.

 

Option D. Canal wall down procedure requires second-look surgery to rule out cholesteatoma recurrence: Incorrect. Second-look surgery is not required in canal wall down procedures due to low recurrence rates.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Canal wall up mastoidectomy maintains normal meatal anatomy and allows easier use of hearing aids, but has a higher risk of residual disease, while canal wall down is safer for disease clearance but has limitations in swimming and hearing aid fitting.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 73
questions.video_explanation_heading: POST OPERATIVE APPEARANCE OF CANAL WALL DOWN MASTOIDECTOMY

choices.text: Acute mastoiditis
Bezold abscess
Petrositis
Labyrinthitis

questions.text: A 14-year-old child presents with persistent ear discharge, deep-seated retro-orbital pain, and diplopia. On examination, the child has lateral rectus palsy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Petrositis

 

  • Classic presentation is Gradenigo syndrome, which includes:
    • Persistent ear discharge
    • Deep-seated retro-orbital pain (trigeminal nerve)
    • Lateral rectus palsy (abducens nerve)
      These findings are pathognomonic for petrous apicitis, caused by spread of infection along pneumatized tracts of the petrous apex.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute mastoiditis: Incorrect. Although it may present with persistent ear discharge and mastoid tenderness, it does not typically involve cranial nerve VI (abducens) or retro-orbital pain.

 

Option B. Bezold abscess: Incorrect. This causes deep neck swelling due to pus tracking from the mastoid tip, but does not involve cranial nerves V or VI, and retro-orbital pain is not a feature.

 

 

Option D. Labyrinthitis: Incorrect. This presents with vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, and possibly tinnitus, but not VIth nerve palsy or retro-orbital pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Petrositis classically presents as Gradenigo syndrome with VIth nerve palsy, retro-orbital pain, and persistent otorrhea, due to infection spreading to the petrous apex along pneumatized tracts.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 79

choices.text: Suppurative labyrinthitis; immediate surgical drainage and systemic corticosteroids
Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo; canalith repositioning and vestibular suppressants
Meniere's disease; sodium restriction and betahistine therapy
Diffuse serous labyrinthitis; systemic antibiotics and possible mastoidectomy if conservative measures fail

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with chronic ear discharge presents with sudden onset vertigo, nausea, and vomiting. Examination reveals spontaneous nystagmus with the quick component toward the affected side. Audiometry shows mild sensorineural hearing loss. Which of the following best describes the underlying condition and its appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diffuse serous labyrinthitis; systemic antibiotics and possible mastoidectomy if conservative measures fail

 

  • Diffuse serous labyrinthitis occurs due to spread of infection from middle ear or cholesteatoma, involving the entire labyrinth. Vertigo, spontaneous nystagmus towards the affected ear, and mild SNHL are key features. Initial management includes systemic antibiotics, labyrinthine sedatives, and bed rest, with mastoidectomy if needed to eliminate infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suppurative labyrinthitis; immediate surgical drainage and systemic corticosteroids: Incorrect. Suppurative labyrinthitis is a more advanced, irreversible condition with total cochleovestibular loss. This patient has partial, reversible symptoms consistent with serous (non-purulent) labyrinthitis.

 

Option B. Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo; canalith repositioning and vestibular suppressants: Incorrect. BPPV is characterized by positional vertigo triggered by head movement, not continuous vertigo with spontaneous nystagmus. No ear discharge or hearing loss is typically associated.

 

Option C. Meniere's disease; sodium restriction and betahistine therapy: Incorrect. Meniere's disease features episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and ear fullness. The quick component of nystagmus is typically away from the affected ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diffuse serous labyrinthitis is a reversible intralabyrinthine inflammation presenting with vertigo, nausea, and SNHL, and is managed with antibiotics, vestibular sedatives, and mastoidectomy if required.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 80

choices.text: Immediate lumbar puncture for CSF analysis
High-dose oral antibiotics and observation
Craniotomy and intravenous antibiotics
Cortical mastoidectomy followed by conservative treatment

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a history of chronic ear discharge presents with headache, fever, neck stiffness, and focal neurological deficits including hemiplegia and aphasia. On examination, he has papilledema and a dilated pupil. MRI shows pus collection between the dura and arachnoid. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Craniotomy and intravenous antibiotics

 

  • This is a classic case of subdural abscess, a serious otogenic intracranial complication. Signs include meningeal irritation (fever, neck rigidity), raised intracranial pressure (papilledema, cranial nerve palsy), and cerebral vein thrombophlebitis (focal deficits like aphasia, hemiplegia). Management requires urgent craniotomy or burr hole drainage and intravenous antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate lumbar puncture for CSF analysis: Incorrect. Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in suspected subdural abscess or any space-occupying lesion due to risk of tonsillar herniation.

 

Option B. High-dose oral antibiotics and observation: Incorrect.  Oral antibiotics and observation are inadequate for this neurosurgical emergency and would delay life-saving intervention.

 

Option D. Cortical mastoidectomy followed by conservative treatment: Incorrect.
Cortical mastoidectomy may be needed later to treat the primary ear source, but the immediate priority is drainage of the subdural pus collection to relieve pressure and control infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subdural abscess from otitis media presents with meningeal signs, focal deficits, and raised intracranial pressure, and requires urgent neurosurgical drainage and intravenous antibiotics; lumbar puncture is contraindicated.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 81

choices.text: Start oral antibiotics and schedule outpatient follow-up
Perform cortical or modified radical mastoidectomy with sinus exposure and IV antibiotics
Proceed directly with ligation of internal jugular vein
Start anticoagulants and observe for resolution

questions.text: A 28-year-old male with a history of chronic suppurative otitis media and recent onset of profuse ear discharge presents with high-grade fever, chills, and rigors. On examination, he has tenderness over the posterior mastoid region (Griesinger’s sign) and papilledema. Contrast-enhanced CT shows a “delta sign” in the posterior cranial fossa. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perform cortical or modified radical mastoidectomy with sinus exposure and IV antibiotics

 

  • This patient has lateral sinus thrombophlebitis secondary to chronic ear infection. Management involves:
    • IV broad-spectrum antibiotics (targeting both aerobes and anaerobes),
    • Cortical/modified radical mastoidectomy (depending on acute vs chronic disease),
    • Exposure and drainage of perisinus abscess or intrasinus clot, if present.
      This is the standard and life-saving approach.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start oral antibiotics and schedule outpatient follow-up: Incorrect. 
Oral antibiotics and outpatient follow-up are inadequate in the setting of intracranial complications like lateral sinus thrombosis. The condition is potentially fatal and requires hospitalization and surgical drainage.

 

Option C. Proceed directly with ligation of internal jugular vein: Incorrect.  Ligation of the internal jugular vein is rarely required and reserved only for persistent embolic phenomena despite surgical and medical treatment.

 

Option D. Start anticoagulants and observe for resolution: Incorrect.  Anticoagulation is rarely indicated unless there is cavernous sinus involvement or propagation of thrombus to the sagittal sinus. Also, anticoagulants alone will not resolve an infected clot or abscess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lateral sinus thrombophlebitis is a serious intracranial complication of otitis media and requires urgent surgical drainage via mastoidectomy along with intravenous antibiotics; Griesinger's sign and "delta sign" on imaging support the diagnosis.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 85

choices.text: Prescribe antihistamines and decongestants
Evaluate the nasopharynx to rule out carcinoma
Insert a grommet after myringotomy
Perform tympanoplasty

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with unilateral hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals a dull tympanic membrane and fluid behind it, suggestive of otitis media with effusion (OME). What should be the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Evaluate the nasopharynx to rule out carcinoma

 

  • In elderly patients, unilateral OME should raise suspicion for nasopharyngeal carcinoma, especially involving the Fossa of Rosenmüller, which can obstruct the Eustachian tube. Nasopharyngoscopy and biopsy are crucial.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prescribe antihistamines and decongestants: Incorrect. While antihistamines and decongestants are used in children or allergic cases, in an elderly patient with unilateral OME, such treatment without further investigation may delay diagnosis of serious pathology.

 

Option C. Insert a grommet after myringotomy: Incorrect. Grommet insertion may relieve symptoms, but doing it before ruling out malignancy may delay appropriate cancer diagnosis and treatment.

 

Option D. Perform tympanoplasty: Incorrect. Tympanoplasty is a reconstructive procedure used in cases of tympanic membrane perforation or chronic otitis media, not in OME.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unilateral otitis media with effusion in an elderly patient should prompt evaluation for nasopharyngeal carcinoma, especially in the Fossa of Rosenmüller.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 251
questions.video_explanation_heading: LEFT UNILATERAL OME, RIGHT EAR NORMAL, LEFT NPC, RIGHT NASOPHARYNX NORMAL

choices.text: Bezold's abscess
Gradenigo’s syndrome
Mastoiditis
Cholesteatoma

questions.text: A 12-year-old child with a history of chronic otitis media presents with deep retro-orbital pain, diplopia, and persistent ear discharge. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Graden go’s syndrome

 

  • This is the correct answer. It results from petrositis, which is infection of the petrous apex of the temporal bone. The trigeminal ganglion (CN V) lies on the anterior surface of the petrous apex, while the abducens nerve (CN VI) runs in Dorello’s canal just beneath it. Classic Gradenigo's triad includes:
    1. Deep retro-orbital pain (due to CN V involvement)
    2. Diplopia (due to lateral rectus palsy from CN VI involvement)
    3. Persistent otorrhea (due to coexistent chronic otitis media)
      Management is surgical.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bezold's abscess: This is a deep neck abscess resulting from mastoiditis spreading into the sternocleidomastoid and digastric muscles through the medial mastoid tip. It does not typically involve cranial nerves or present with retro-orbital pain and diplopia.

 

 

Option C. Mastoiditis: Although mastoiditis can cause ear discharge and pain, it does not usually lead to cranial nerve palsies or retro-orbital pain unless it progresses to petrositis.

 

Option D. Cholesteatoma: Cholesteatoma can erode bone and cause chronic ear discharge, but the classical triad of Gradenigo’s syndrome involving cranial nerves V and VI is specific to petrous apex involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gradenigo’s syndrome, seen in petrositis, presents with retro-orbital pain (CN V), diplopia (CN VI), and persistent otorrhea and is managed surgically.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 94

choices.text: Cortical mastoidectomy
Tympanoplasty for anterior perforation
Grommet insertion in otitis media with effusion
Exposure of vertical segment of facial nerve

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a standard indication for performing a postaural (Wilde’s) incision in ENT surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Grommet insertion in otitis media with effusion

 

  • This is the correct answer. Grommet (ventilation tube) insertion is a minimally invasive procedure done via the transcanal route (through the external auditory canal), not requiring a postaural incision.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cortical mastoidectomy: This is a valid indication. Postaural incision provides excellent access to the mastoid cortex and is routinely used in cortical mastoidectomy procedures.

 

Option B. Tympanoplasty for anterior perforation: When the perforation extends anterior to the handle of malleus, visualization through the ear canal is difficult. A postaural approach helps in such tympanoplasties to improve access and graft placement.

 

Option D. Exposure of vertical segment of facial nerve: Postaural incision is used in surgeries requiring facial nerve exposure, especially in the vertical (mastoid) segment, such as in facial nerve decompression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postaural (Wilde’s) incision is used in mastoid surgeries, tympanoplasty with anterior perforations, and to expose the vertical facial nerve segment—not for simple transcanal procedures like grommet insertion.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 401

choices.text: It uses a 15° cephalocaudal beam and does not show the attic or antrum clearly
It is primarily used to assess nasopharyngeal tumors extending into the Eustachian tube
It shows the key area of the mastoid including antrum and upper attic, using a 30° cephalocaudal beam
The sagittal plane is perpendicular to the film and the internal and external auditory canals are separated

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes Schuller’s view in radiological imaging of the temporal bone?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It shows the key area of the mastoid including antrum and upper attic, using a 30° cephalocaudal beam

 

  • Schuller’s view is similar to Law’s but uses a 30° cephalocaudal beam, and clearly shows the key mastoid area—antrum, attic, sinodural angle, and helps assess pneumatization, cholesteatoma, and fractures.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It uses a 15° cephalocaudal beam and does not show the attic or antrum clearly: This is a description of Law’s view, not Schuller’s. Law’s view uses a 15° beam and does not visualize the key area well.

 

Option B. It is primarily used to assess nasopharyngeal tumors extending into the Eustachian tube: Incorrect. Schuller’s view is for temporal bone and mastoid imaging, not for soft tissue structures of the nasopharynx.

 

Option D. The sagittal plane is perpendicular to the film and the internal and external auditory canals are separated: Incorrect. As with Law’s view, in Schuller’s view, the sagittal plane is parallel to the film, and the EAC is superimposed on the IAC, not separated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schuller’s view uses a 30° cephalocaudal beam with the sagittal plane parallel to the film and is useful for visualizing the mastoid antrum, attic, and sinodural angle, making it ideal for assessing mastoiditis, cholesteatoma, and petrous fractures.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 433

choices.text: It is used to remove granulation tissue from the middle ear in CSOM
It is used to incise the tympanic membrane during myringotomy
It is a curette used to excise the adenoids
It is used to raise the tympanomeatal flap in tympanoplasty

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is a myringotome. Which of the following statements regarding this instrument and its use is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is used to incise the tympanic membrane during myringotomy

 

  • The instrument shown is a myringotome, a fine, angled knife used to make a precise incision in the tympanic membrane (typically in the anteroinferior quadrant) during myringotomy. This is commonly done to drain middle ear fluid or insert a ventilation tube (grommet).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Removal of granulation tissue in CSOM: This is typically done with cup forceps or suction instruments, not with a myringotome.

 

 

Option C. Adenoid curette: The adenoid curette (La Force or St Clair Thompson) is used for adenoidectomy, not this instrument.

 

 

Option D. Tympanomeatal flap elevation: This is done with instruments like the Rosen’s or Freer’s elevator, not a myringotome.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A myringotome is a surgical instrument used to make a controlled incision in the tympanic membrane during myringotomy, often for middle ear drainage or grommet insertion.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 451

choices.text: It is used for nasal septum elevation during septoplasty
It is manually held throughout mastoid surgery to retract soft tissues
It is self-retaining and commonly used to retract soft tissue flaps during mastoidectomy
It is used to excise granulation tissue from the middle ear cavity

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is Jansen’s self-retaining mastoid retractor. Which of the following statements regarding this instrument is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is self-retaining and commonly used to retract soft tissue flaps during mastoidectomy

 

  • Jansen’s self-retaining mastoid retractor is used during mastoid surgery to retract the postaural soft tissues after flap elevation. It has two sharp prongs on either side and a screw mechanism to hold it in place. It is similar in function to Mollison’s retractor, but with a different locking mechanism and blade configuration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasal septum elevation: This is typically done with a Freer’s elevator, not Jansen’s retractor.

 

 

Option B. Manually held throughout mastoid surgery: Incorrect. One of the advantages of Jansen’s retractor is that it is self-retaining, meaning it stays in place without needing to be held, freeing up the assistant's hands.

 

Option D. Removal of granulation tissue: This is done using cup forceps or suction tips, not with a retractor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Jansen’s self-retaining mastoid retractor is used in mastoidectomy to retract soft tissues after flap elevation and provides a stable, hands-free operative field.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 451

choices.text: It is used to elevate the tympanomeatal flap in tympanoplasty
It is used to suction fluid from the middle ear during myringotomy
It is used to remove bone during mastoid surgery and comes in various sizes
It is primarily used to cauterize granulation tissue in the ear canal

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is a mastoid gouge. Which of the following statements about its use is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is used to remove bone during mastoid surgery and comes in various sizes

 

  • The mastoid gouge is a manual instrument with a chisel-like edge, used during mastoidectomy to remove bone, especially when a drill is not used. Available in various sizes, it allows the surgeon to carve through mastoid bone systematically.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tympanomeatal flap elevation: This is done using an elevator such as Freer’s or Rosen’s, not a gouge.

 

Option B. Suction of middle ear fluid: Suction tips or cannulas are used during procedures like myringotomy, not gouges.

 

Option D. Cauterization of granulation tissue: Granulation tissue is removed or cauterized using chemical agents or electrocautery, not a gouge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mastoid gouge is a manual surgical instrument available in various sizes and used to remove bone during mastoid surgery.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 452

choices.text: Freer’s elevator – used to elevate nasal septal flaps
Farabeuf periosteal elevator – used to elevate periosteum from mastoid cortex in mastoidectomy
Lempert’s endaural speculum – used to spread the external auditory canal during endaural approach
Mollison’s mastoid retractor – used to retract postaural soft tissues during mastoid surgery

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and choose the correct statement regarding its surgical use:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Farabeuf periosteal elevator – used to elevate periosteum from mastoid cortex in mastoidectomy

 

  • The instrument shown is the Farabeuf periosteal elevator, which has a flat, wide handle and curved working end. It is used in mastoidectomy to elevate the periosteum from the mastoid cortex after the postaural incision and flap elevation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Freer’s elevator: This is a double-ended elevator with blunt tips used to elevate mucoperichondrial flaps, especially in nasal surgeries—not for lifting periosteum from bone.

 

 

Option C. Lempert’s endaural speculum: This is a speculum-like instrument used to spread open the external auditory canal during endaural procedures—not an elevator.

 

 

Option D. Mollison’s retractor: Mollison’s is a self-retaining retractor used to keep postaural flaps retracted, not to elevate periosteum.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Farabeuf periosteal elevator is used in mastoidectomy to elevate the periosteum from the mastoid cortex after postaural flap elevation.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 452

choices.text: Stage of tubal occlusion
Stage of presuppuration
Stage of suppuration
Stage of resolution

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with complaints of fever, severe earache, vomiting, and reduced hearing. Otoscopic examination reveals a bulging, red tympanic membrane with loss of landmarks, and a yellow spot is visible. What stage of Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM) is this child most likely in?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stage of suppuration

 

Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM) evolves in five classic stages:

 

1. Stage of Tubal Occlusion:

 

  • Cause: Eustachian tube blockage due to URTI
  • TM: Retraction, horizontal malleus handle, dull cone of light
  • Symptoms: Mild earache, conductive hearing loss
  • No fever, usually no visible fluid

 

2. Stage of Presuppuration:

 

  • TM: Red, congested, "cart-wheel" appearance
  • Symptoms: Marked earache, fever, restlessness, tinnitus
  • Exudate begins to form in middle ear

 

3. Stage of Suppuration (Answer):

 

  • TM: Bulging, red, yellow spot (site of imminent rupture), loss of landmarks
  • Symptoms: Severe earache, high fever (102–103°F), vomiting, possibly convulsions
  • Pus starts to collect in middle ear & mastoid

 

4. Stage of Resolution:

 

  • TM ruptures → pus drains
  • Relief of pain, fever subsides
  • Perforation often in anteroinferior quadrant, discharge becomes mucopurulent

 

5. Stage of Complication:

 

  • If untreated or virulent organism:
    • Mastoiditis, labyrinthitis, facial palsy, meningitis, brain abscess, etc.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage of tubal occlusion: Only mild retraction and deafness, not fever or bulging TM

 

Option B. Stage of presuppuration: TM is red but not bulging; no yellow spot

 

Option D. Stage of resolution: TM has ruptured, symptoms start improving

 

Educational Objective:

 

The suppurative stage of ASOM is marked by bulging tympanic membrane, yellow spot, severe earache, and high fever, indicating accumulation of pus in the middle ear.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 62

choices.text: Acute bacterial infection of the middle ear
Inflammation of cochlear membranes due to viral labyrinthitis
Failure of Eustachian tube to equalize middle ear pressure during descent
Serous otitis media due to allergic rhinitis

questions.text: A 25-year-old man experiences sudden severe ear pain, hearing loss, and a sense of fullness in the right ear during rapid descent on a flight. Otoscopy reveals a congested, retracted tympanic membrane, and audiometry shows conductive hearing loss. What is the most likely underlying mechanism of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Failure of Eustachian tube to equalize middle ear pressure during descent

 

The patient has aero-otitis media (barotraumatic otitis), a nonsuppurative condition caused by sudden pressure changes during flight or diving, especially during descent.

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • During descent, ambient air pressure increases rapidly
  • If Eustachian tube fails to open, the middle ear cannot be re-aerated, creating a negative pressure
  • This causes:
    • Tympanic membrane retraction
    • Transudation/bleeding
    • Sometimes rupture of TM or labyrinthine membranes
  • “Tube locking” occurs when nasopharyngeal pressure exceeds middle ear pressure by >90 mm Hg

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Sudden ear pain, conductive hearing loss, tinnitus
  • Vertigo (if inner ear involved)
  • TM appears retracted, congested, may show hemorrhagic effusion
  • Hearing loss is conductive, occasionally sensorineural

 

Treatment:

 

  • Decongestants, antihistamines
  • Politzerization/catheterization
  • Myringotomy in severe or fluid-filled cases

 

Prevention:

 

  • Avoid travel during URIs/allergies
  • Chewing gum, sucking sweets, frequent swallowing
  • Use nasal sprays, antihistamines, and decongestants before descent
  • Perform Valsalva intermittently

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute bacterial infection of the middle ear:  Incorrect. No signs of infection (fever, purulent discharge)

 

Option B. Inflammation of cochlear membranes due to viral labyrinthitis: Incorrect. Viral labyrinthitis causes vertigo + SNHL, not pressure-related ear pain

 

Option D. Serous otitis media due to allergic rhinitis:  Incorrect. While allergy can contribute to ET dysfunction, it is not the primary mechanism here

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aero-otitis media occurs when the Eustachian tube fails to equalize middle ear pressure during descent, leading to TM retraction, pain, and conductive hearing loss.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 66

choices.text: Ruedi’s theory
Wittmaack’s theory
Sade’s theory
Habermann’s theory

questions.text: Which of the following theories of cholesteatoma origin involves retraction pocket formation due to invagination of tympanic membrane epithelium?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wittmaack’s theory

 

Cholesteatoma is defined as the presence of keratinizing squamous epithelium within the middle ear cleft, where it is not normally present. Several theories have been proposed to explain its origin, particularly how this epithelium gains access to the middle ear.

 

Key Theories of Cholesteatoma Formation:

 

  1. Wittmaack’s Theory (Invagination Theory)
    • Describes formation of retraction pockets from attic or posterosuperior pars tensa
    • Outer epithelium invaginates and lays down keratin
    • Most widely accepted in acquired cholesteatoma
  2. Ruedi’s Theory (Basal Cell Hyperplasia)
    • Infection stimulates basal cell proliferation
    • Forms keratinizing squamous epithelium
  3. Habermann’s Theory (Epithelial Invasion)
    • Squamous epithelium migrates from EAC into middle ear via pre-existing marginal perforation
  4. Sade’s Theory (Metaplasia Theory)
    • Respiratory epithelium of middle ear undergoes metaplasia to squamous epithelium due to chronic infection
  5. Congenital Theory
    • Epithelial rests remain in the middle ear from embryonic development and give rise to cholesteatoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ruedi’s theory:  Basal cell proliferation theory, not retraction

 

Option C. Sade’s theory: Involves metaplasia, not invagination

 

Option D. Habermann’s theory: Involves epithelial migration through a perforation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wittmaack’s theory explains cholesteatoma formation due to retraction pocket of tympanic membrane epithelium invaginating into the middle ear.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 67

choices.text: Associated with tympanic membrane perforation
Presents as a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane
Occurs due to epithelial migration through a marginal perforation
Typically arises from retraction pocket of pars flaccida or pars tensa

questions.text: Which of the following features helps differentiate congenital cholesteatoma from acquired cholesteatoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presents as a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Associated with tympanic membrane perforation: Tympanic membrane perforation is a feature of acquired cholesteatoma

 

Option C. Occurs due to epithelial migration through a marginal perforation: Describes Habermann's theory. a feature of acquired cholesteatoma

 

Option D. Typically arises from retraction pocket of pars flaccida or pars tensa: Describes retraction pocket origin (Wittmaack’s theory) – seen in acquired cholesteatoma

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital cholesteatoma presents as a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane, while acquired cholesteatoma is associated with retraction pockets or TM perforation.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 67

choices.text: Tubotympanic type of CSOM
Serous otitis media
Atticoantral type of CSOM
Otitis externa

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with complaints of persistent ear discharge that is foul-smelling and scanty. Otoscopic examination reveals a marginal perforation in the posterosuperior quadrant, and granulation tissue is seen. Audiometry reveals mixed hearing loss. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Atticoantral type of CSOM

 

  • Atticoantral type of CSOM: Also known as the “unsafe” type. Characterized by scanty, purulent, foul-smelling discharge, attic or marginal perforation, red, fleshy granulations, and often associated with cholesteatoma and complications. Mixed hearing loss may be present due to both ossicular damage and inner ear involvement.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubotympanic type of CSOM: This is known as the “safe” type. It presents with profuse, mucoid, odourless discharge, central perforation, pale granulations (if present), and conductive hearing loss. Not consistent with this case.

 

 

Option B. Serous otitis media: Typically presents with non-foul smelling fluid (serous/mucoid), no perforation, and hearing loss that is mostly conductive and mild. This does not match the clinical picture.

 

 

Option D. Otitis externa: Involves the external auditory canal, typically causes pain, swelling, and discharge, but not a perforation or granulation tissue seen via otoscopy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atticoantral (unsafe) CSOM is characterized by scanty, foul-smelling discharge, marginal or attic perforation, granulations, and a higher risk of complications and mixed hearing loss.

 

Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 69

choices.text: Diffuse serous labyrinthitis due to acute otitis media, ampullofugal endolymph flow
Circumscribed labyrinthitis with ampullopetal displacement of the cupula
Meniere’s disease with increased endolymphatic pressure in saccule and utricle
Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo with canalithiasis in posterior semicircular canal

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with chronic ear discharge and recent onset vertigo complains of dizziness while cleaning his ear or during Valsalva. On examination, applying pressure on the tragus elicits vertigo and horizontal nystagmus towards the same side. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and associated mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Circumscribed labyrinthitis with ampullopetal displacement of the cupula.

 

  • Circumscribed labyrinthitis occurs due to erosion of bony labyrinth, most commonly of the horizontal semicircular canal in chronic suppurative otitis media with cholesteatoma. Positive fistula test leads to ampullopetal displacement of cupula → nystagmus towards affected ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diffuse serous labyrinthitis due to acute otitis media, ampullofugal endolymph flow: Incorrect. Diffuse serous labyrinthitis involves inflammation of the entire labyrinth usually in acute infections and not limited to pressure-induced vertigo. Ampullofugal flow causes nystagmus away from the affected side.

 

Option C. Meniere’s disease with increased endolymphatic pressure in saccule and utricle: Incorrect. Meniere’s disease presents with episodic vertigo, tinnitus, and fluctuating hearing loss, but is not induced by pressure on tragus or Valsalva.

 

Option D. Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo with canalithiasis in posterior semicircular canal: Incorrect. BPPV involves positional vertigo, typically with Dix-Hallpike test; not pressure-induced. Nystagmus is not specific to tragal pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Circumscribed labyrinthitis, commonly due to cholesteatoma, presents with pressure-induced vertigo and nystagmus towards the affected side due to ampullopetal endolymph flow.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 80

choices.text: Temporal lobe glioma; initiate radiotherapy immediately
Otogenic brain abscess; initiate intravenous antibiotics and consider neurosurgical drainage
Cerebellar stroke; manage with anticoagulants and supportive care
Subarachnoid hemorrhage; confirm with lumbar puncture and manage in ICU

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a long-standing history of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) presents with severe headache, vomiting, drowsiness, and right-sided hemiparesis. CT scan reveals a ring-enhancing lesion in the left temporal lobe. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the appropriate approach?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Otogenic brain abscess; initiate intravenous antibiotics and consider neurosurgical drainage

 

  • The patient has signs of raised intracranial tension (headache, vomiting, drowsiness), focal neurological deficit (right-sided hemiparesis due to left temporal involvement), and a history of CSOM, making otogenic brain abscess the most likely diagnosis. Management includes high-dose IV antibiotics (like third-generation cephalosporins + metronidazole) and neurosurgical intervention (aspiration or excision). Otologic surgery (e.g., radical mastoidectomy) is done once abscess control is achieved.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Temporal lobe glioma; initiate radiotherapy immediately: Incorrect. 
Temporal lobe glioma presents more insidiously and does not typically cause acute raised intracranial pressure or papilledema unless large. Also, ring-enhancing lesion on CT in the context of chronic ear disease favors abscess, not tumor.

 

Option C. Cerebellar stroke; manage with anticoagulants and supportive care: Incorrect. Cerebellar stroke presents with vertigo, ataxia, and vomiting, but this case lacks cerebellar signs (e.g., ipsilateral hypotonia, past pointing). CSOM history and CT findings also argue against stroke.

 

Option D. Subarachnoid hemorrhage; confirm with lumbar puncture and manage in ICU: Incorrect. Subarachnoid hemorrhage causes sudden severe headache (“thunderclap”) and may show blood in basal cisterns on CT. Lumbar puncture is contraindicated if raised ICP is suspected, due to the risk of brain herniation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otogenic brain abscess commonly complicates chronic suppurative otitis media and presents with raised intracranial pressure and focal neurological signs; management includes antibiotics, neurosurgical drainage, and subsequent mastoid surgery.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 83

choices.text: Fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss – Otosclerosis
Fluctuating conductive hearing loss – Otitis media with effusion
Fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss – Presbycusis
Fluctuating conductive hearing loss – Meniere’s disease

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with intermittent hearing difficulty. Otoscopy reveals a dull, retracted tympanic membrane with visible air-fluid levels. Audiometry suggests a fluctuating hearing loss. What is the most likely type of hearing loss and its associated condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluctuating conductive hearing loss – Otitis media with effusion

 

  • In OME (Otitis Media with Effusion), middle ear fluid intermittently affects the movement of the tympanic membrane and ossicles, causing fluctuating conductive hearing loss, particularly in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss – Otosclerosis: Incorrect. Otosclerosis causes progressive conductive hearing loss, not fluctuating sensorineural loss.

 

Option C. Fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss – Presbycusis: Incorrect. Presbycusis causes a gradual, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, not fluctuating.

 

Option D. Fluctuating conductive hearing loss – Meniere’s disease: Incorrect. Meniere’s disease causes fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, not conductive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluctuating conductive hearing loss is characteristic of otitis media with effusion, whereas fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss is seen in Meniere’s disease.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 115, 243

choices.text: It reliably detects fistulas involving the posterior semicircular canal
The test is done with the patient sitting upright with head in neutral position
Cold water irrigation normally causes nystagmus to the same side
Normal nystagmus response follows the COWS pattern – Cold Opposite, Warm Same

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test used to detect perilymph fistula?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Normal nystagmus response follows the COWS pattern – Cold Opposite, Warm Same

 

  • In normal physiology, caloric stimulation of the lateral semicircular canal produces predictable nystagmus responses:
    • Cold water → Opposite side nystagmus
    • Warm water → Same side nystagmus
      This pattern is disrupted in perilymph fistula, indicating abnormal vestibular function.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. I It reliably detects fistulas involving the posterior semicircular canal:  Incorrect.  Posterior canal: involvement is not reliably detected by this test. The Fitzgerald-Hallpike caloric test specifically stimulates the lateral semicircular canal, not the superior or posterior canals.

 

Option B. The test is done with the patient sitting upright with head in neutral position:  Incorrect. Positioning The test is performed with the patient supine and head tilted forward by 30° to bring the lateral semicircular canal in horizontal plane, not in a neutral upright position.

 

Option C. Cold water irrigation normally causes nystagmus to the same side: Incorrect. Cold water effect. Cold water stimulation causes nystagmus to the opposite side in normal individuals, not the same side.

 

Educational Objective:


Fitzgerald-Hallpike caloric test stimulates the lateral semicircular canal and in normal individuals, produces nystagmus following the COWS rule—Cold Opposite, Warm Same.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 43

choices.text: Eustachian tube
Arcuate eminence and petrous pyramid
Nasopharynx and skull base
Frontal sinus and ethmoid air cells

questions.text: Which of the following structures is best visualized in a Stenver’s view of the temporal bone?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arcuate eminence and petrous pyramid

 

  • In Stenver’s view, the long axis of the petrous bone is made parallel to the film, and it provides a clear view of:
    • Entire petrous pyramid
    • Arcuate eminence
    • Internal auditory meatus
    • Vestibule and cochlea (labyrinth)
    • Mastoid antrum

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eustachian tube: Not visualized in Stenver’s view. This view is meant for imaging bony structures of the temporal bone, not the cartilaginous Eustachian tube.

 

Option C. Nasopharynx and skull base: These are best visualized in lateral skull base or base-of-skull CT views, not in Stenver’s view.

 

Option D. Frontal sinus and ethmoid air cells: Best seen in Waters’ view or CT PNS, not Stenver’s view which targets the temporal bone structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stenver’s view aligns the petrous ridge parallel to the film and is used to visualize the petrous pyramid, arcuate eminence, internal auditory meatus, cochlea, vestibule, and mastoid antrum.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 433

choices.text: X-ray beam is directed cephalocaudally with occiput on the film
It visualizes external auditory canal, middle ear cleft, sphenoid sinus, and carotid canal
It is primarily used to assess frontal and ethmoid sinuses
It fails to demonstrate foramina at the base of skull like foramen ovale and spinosum

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the Submentovertical (SMV) view used in radiological imaging of the skull base?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It visualizes external auditory canal, middle ear cleft, sphenoid sinus, and carotid canal

 

  • The SMV view clearly shows multiple structures at the base of skull, including:
    • External auditory canal (EAC)
    • Middle ear cleft (mastoid air cells, middle ear, Eustachian tube)
    • Internal auditory canal
    • Sphenoid sinus
    • Carotid canal
    • Foramen ovale and foramen spinosum
      It provides excellent visualization of both bony and air-filled structures at the skull base.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. X-ray beam directed cephalocaudally with occiput on the film: This refers to Towne’s view, not SMV. In Submentovertical view, the vertex (top of the head) is placed near the film, and the X-ray beam is projected upward from the submental area at a right angle to the film.

 

Option C. Primarily for frontal and ethmoid sinuses: This is incorrect. Frontal and ethmoid sinuses are better assessed in Caldwell’s or Waters’ view, not SMV.

 

Option D. Fails to demonstrate foramina like ovale and spinosum: Incorrect. SMV view is one of the best views to see foramen ovale and foramen spinosum, along with the carotid canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The submentovertical (SMV) view visualizes the EAC, middle ear cleft, internal auditory canal, sphenoid sinus, carotid canal, and skull base foramina like foramen ovale and spinosum.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 433

choices.text: It is used to remove granulation tissue from the middle ear
It is used for retraction of soft tissues in the postaural approach
It is used in the endaural approach and has a central blade that retracts the temporalis muscle
It is used for elevating the tympanomeatal flap during tympanoplasty

questions.text: The instrument shown is Lempert’s endaural retractor. Which of the following statements regarding this instrument is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is used in the endaural approach and has a central blade that retracts the temporalis muscle

 

  • Lempert’s endaural retractor has two lateral blades to retract the skin flaps and a central blade (with multiple holes) to retract the temporalis muscle. The central blade can be fixed at varying positions using the holes on the main body of the retractor, providing customized exposure in ear surgeries using the endaural approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Used to remove granulation tissue: This task is typically performed using cup forceps or suction tips, not a retractor like Lempert’s.

 

Option B. Used in postaural approach: Lempert’s retractor is specifically designed for the endaural approach, not for the postaural (Wilde’s) approach.

 

Option D. Used for elevating tympanomeatal flap: This is done with an elevator such as a Freer’s or Rosen’s elevator, not with this retractor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lempert’s endaural retractor is used in the endaural approach to ear surgery, with lateral blades retracting skin flaps and a central blade to retract the temporalis muscle.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 452

choices.text: Lempert’s curette – used for removal of bony septa and granulations in mastoid surgery
Freer’s elevator – used to elevate tympanomeatal flap
Myringotome – used for incision in tympanic membrane
Mollison’s retractor – used for soft tissue retraction in postaural mastoidectomy

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and select the correct statement regarding its use:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lempert’s curette – used for removal of bony septa and granulations in mastoid surgery

 

  • The instrument shown is Lempert’s curette (also called Lempert’s scoop). It has a rounded scoop-like end and is commonly used in mastoidectomy to remove bony septa between air cells and clear out granulation tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Freer’s elevator: Freer’s elevator is a double-ended blunt instrument used to elevate flaps, especially during septoplasty, not for bone or granulation removal.

 

 

Option C. Myringotome: A myringotome is a fine angled knife used to make a precise incision in the tympanic membrane, not to remove bone or granulations.

 

 

Option D. Mollison’s retractor: This is a self-retaining retractor used for soft tissue retraction in postaural approaches, not a curette.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lempert’s curette is used in mastoidectomy to remove bony septa and granulation tissue from the mastoid air cells.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 452

choices.text: Mild earache with no tympanic membrane bulging
Acute pain with bulging tympanic membrane despite antibiotic therapy
Resolution of symptoms after 3 days of antibiotic therapy
Conductive hearing loss persisting for 1 week after symptom relief

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct indication for myringotomy in the treatment of Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute pain with bulging tympanic membrane despite antibiotic therapy

 

Persistent bulging and pain are valid indications for myringotomy

 

Treatment of ASOM is multimodal and tailored based on the stage and severity. 

 

Key components include:

 

1. Antibiotic Therapy

 

  • Indicated in all cases with fever and severe earache
  • First-line: Amoxicillin (40 mg/kg/day) or Ampicillin
  • In penicillin allergy: Cefaclor, co-trimoxazole, erythromycin
  • In β-lactamase–producing H. influenzae or M. catarrhalis:
    → Amoxicillin-clavulanate, cefixime, cefuroxime axetil
  • Continue for minimum 10 days to prevent secretory otitis media

 

2. Nasal Decongestants

 

  • Ephedrine, xylometazoline, oxymetazoline → relieve ET edema
  • Also, oral pseudoephedrine or combination with antihistamine

 

3. Supportive Care

 

  • Paracetamol for pain and fever
  • Ear toilet for discharge (dry mopping + antibiotic wick)
  • Dry heat for symptomatic relief

 

4. Myringotomy Indications

 

  • Bulging TM with severe acute pain
  • Incomplete resolution despite antibiotic therapy
  • Persistent middle ear effusion >12 weeks

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Mild earache with no tympanic membrane bulging: Mild cases without bulging can be treated conservatively; no myringotomy

 

Option C. Resolution of symptoms after 3 days of antibiotic therapy: Resolution after 3 days is expected, no need for surgery

 

Option D. Conductive hearing loss persisting for 1 week after symptom relief: 1-week conductive loss may still be resolving; 12 weeks effusion is the threshold for intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myringotomy is indicated in ASOM when there is persistent pain with bulging tympanic membrane, incomplete resolution despite antibiotics, or effusion lasting more than 12 weeks.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 62

choices.text: Perforation due to acute otitis media
Epithelial migration through a marginal perforation
Invagination of pars flaccida due to persistent negative pressure
Direct extension from congenital epithelial rests

questions.text: A 12-year-old child with no prior history of ear discharge or otitis media is found to have a retraction pocket in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane, with visible keratin debris. Otoscopy confirms attic perforation. What is the most likely underlying mechanism for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Invagination of pars flaccida due to persistent negative pressure

 

  • This is the most accepted theory for primary acquired cholesteatoma, where negative middle ear pressure causes pars flaccida to invaginate, trapping keratin debris. Over time, this forms a retraction pocket that evolves into a cholesteatoma. This explains the attic perforation as the proximal extension of the sac.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perforation due to acute otitis media: is incorrect. Acute otitis media causes suppurative perforation, usually in pars tensa, not a keratinizing retraction pocket in pars flaccida.

 

Option B. Epithelial migration through a marginal perforation: Describes epithelial invasion theory (Habermann’s theory), typical for secondary acquired cholesteatoma where there is a pre-existing perforation – not applicable in primary acquired type.

 

Option D. Direct extension from congenital epithelial rests: Relates to congenital cholesteatoma, not applicable here as the child has no history of congenital findings or presentation behind intact tympanic membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary acquired cholesteatoma most commonly arises due to invagination of pars flaccida from persistent negative pressure, forming a retraction pocket that accumulates keratin and expands toward the middle ear.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 67

choices.text: Acute Suppurative Otitis Media
Cholesteatomatous Otitis Media
Tubercular Otitis Media
Otomycosis

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with painless ear discharge, multiple tympanic membrane perforations, and sudden-onset facial paralysis. Examination reveals pale granulations in the middle ear, and the hearing loss is severe and out of proportion to clinical findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tubercular Otitis Media

 

  • Classic features include painless foul-smelling discharge, multiple tympanic membrane perforations, severe hearing loss disproportionate to symptoms, and early facial paralysis. Seen commonly in children, often secondary to pulmonary or lymph node TB.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Suppurative Otitis Media: Typically presents with earache, fever, single perforation, and mucopurulent discharge. Multiple perforations and painless discharge are not characteristic.

 

 

Option B. Cholesteatomatous Otitis Media: Can cause bone erosion and hearing loss but doesn’t typically present with multiple tympanic perforations, and facial palsy is usually secondary and less sudden.

 

 

Option D. Otomycosis: Presents with itching, discharge with fungal debris, and mild conductive hearing loss. It doesn’t typically cause perforations or facial palsy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tubercular Otitis Media presents with painless discharge, multiple tympanic membrane perforations, severe hearing loss, and early facial paralysis, especially in children.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 74

choices.text: Permanent nerve damage is likely and urgent decompression is mandatory
Facial nerve paralysis is due to cholesteatoma-induced destruction of the facial canal
Facial nerve recovery is expected with systemic antibiotics, and surgery may be needed in resistant cases
Facial paralysis is due to vestibular schwannoma arising in the internal auditory canal

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with acute otitis media develops sudden onset facial asymmetry. On otoscopy, bulging of the tympanic membrane is noted. Which of the following is most likely true regarding this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Facial nerve recovery is expected with systemic antibiotics, and surgery may be needed in resistant cases

 

  • In acute otitis media, inflammation can spread to the facial nerve through dehiscent bony canal, causing facial palsy. This usually resolves with appropriate systemic antibiotics, though myringotomy or mastoidectomy may be needed if there's no improvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Permanent nerve damage is likely and urgent decompression is mandatory: Incorrect. In acute otitis media, facial nerve damage is typically reversible, especially when treated early with antibiotics. Permanent damage is uncommon unless the disease progresses or is neglected.

 

Option B. Facial nerve paralysis is due to cholesteatoma-induced destruction of the facial canal: Incorrect. This is true for chronic otitis media with cholesteatoma, not for acute cases. In chronic cases, bony destruction of the facial canal may occur due to cholesteatoma.

 

Option D. Facial paralysis is due to vestibular schwannoma arising in the internal auditory canal: Incorrect. Vestibular schwannoma presents with gradual sensorineural hearing loss and late facial symptoms, not acute facial paralysis with signs of otitis media.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Facial paralysis in acute otitis media is typically reversible with systemic antibiotics, though surgery like myringotomy or mastoidectomy may be indicated in resistant cases.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 80

choices.text: Diffuse serous labyrinthitis
Diffuse suppurative labyrinthitis
Meniere’s disease
Vestibular neuronitis

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with chronic ear infection develops sudden severe vertigo, vomiting, and complete hearing loss in one ear. Examination reveals spontaneous nystagmus with the quick component directed to the opposite ear. He appears toxic. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diffuse suppurative labyrinthitis

 

  • Diffuse suppurative labyrinthitis is characterized by severe vestibular failure, spontaneous nystagmus with quick component to the healthy side (due to destruction of affected labyrinth), total hearing loss, and systemic toxicity. It is irreversible and may lead to intracranial complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diffuse serous labyrinthitis: Incorrect. Serous labyrinthitis is non-purulent, usually reversible, and presents with milder symptoms. In this case, the severe vertigo, complete hearing loss, and toxic appearance suggest a more advanced stage.

 

Option C. Meniere’s disease: Incorrect. Meniere’s disease presents with fluctuating SNHL, tinnitus, episodic vertigo, and ear fullness—not with complete hearing loss and toxicity.

 

Option D. Vestibular neuronitis: Incorrect. Vestibular neuronitis causes vertigo without hearing loss and typically occurs in otherwise healthy individuals. It lacks the systemic toxicity seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diffuse suppurative labyrinthitis presents with severe vertigo, vomiting, complete hearing loss, and spontaneous nystagmus toward the healthy side, and requires urgent antibiotic therapy and possible surgical intervention.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 81

choices.text: It is most commonly associated with otitis externa in children
Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in all cases of suspected meningitis
CT scan is the definitive diagnostic test for bacterial meningitis
It is the most common intracranial complication of otitis media in children

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with high-grade fever, neck rigidity, photophobia, vomiting, and altered sensorium. He had a history of ear discharge for the past few days. CSF analysis reveals turbid fluid, high protein, low glucose, and predominant polymorphs. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is the most common intracranial complication of otitis media in children

 

  • Meningitis is indeed the most common intracranial complication of otitis media, especially in infants and children. In adults, it is more commonly associated with chronic otitis media with cholesteatoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is most commonly associated with otitis externa in children: Incorrect.
Otogenic meningitis is linked to otitis media, not otitis externa. Acute otitis media in children is a common cause, particularly when infection spreads to the meninges.

 

Option B. Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in all cases of suspected meningitis:  Incorrect. Lumbar puncture is not contraindicated in all cases. It is essential for diagnosis, unless there are signs of raised intracranial pressure or other contraindications (e.g., risk of herniation). In such cases, neuroimaging is performed first.

 

Option C. CT scan is the definitive diagnostic test for bacterial meningitis: Incorrect. CT/MRI helps rule out associated complications like abscesses or sinus thrombosis but CSF examination via lumbar puncture is the diagnostic gold standard for meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meningitis is the most frequent intracranial complication of otitis media, diagnosed via CSF analysis and treated with antibiotics and, when needed, mastoid surgery.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 82

choices.text: Pyogenic meningitis
Otitic hydrocephalus
Subdural abscess
Tuberculous meningitis

questions.text: A 12-year-old child with a recent history of chronic otitis media presents with severe headache, diplopia, and episodes of blurred vision. Fundoscopy shows papilloedema. CSF examination reveals an opening pressure of 310 mm H₂O but normal cell counts, proteins, sugars, and sterile cultures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Otitic hydrocephalus

 

  • Otitic hydrocephalus is a condition of raised intracranial pressure with normal CSF findings, typically seen in children or adolescents with acute or chronic middle ear infections. It is associated with lateral sinus thrombosis that impedes venous drainage and may involve the superior sagittal sinus, affecting CSF absorption. Key features include:
    • Severe headache, vomiting
    • Diplopia (VI nerve palsy)
    • Papilloedema
    • CSF opening pressure >300 mm H₂O with normal composition

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyogenic meningitis: Incorrect because pyogenic meningitis shows raised CSF pressure along with high protein, low glucose, and neutrophilic pleocytosis. In this case, CSF is biochemically and cytologically normal, making meningitis unlikely.

 

Option C. Subdural abscess: Subdural abscess usually presents with focal neurological deficits, altered mental status, and signs of meningeal irritation, and CSF is not typically normal. Imaging helps confirm it.

 

Option D. Tuberculous meningitis: This typically shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, high protein, and low sugar in CSF. Here, the CSF is sterile and normal in contents, ruling it out.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otitic hydrocephalus presents with raised intracranial pressure and normal CSF findings, typically due to lateral sinus thrombosis following middle ear infection.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 85

choices.text: Type I
Type II
Type III
Type IV

questions.text: Which of the following Wullstein types of tympanoplasty is indicated when the malleus and incus are absent, and the graft is placed directly over the stapes head?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type III

 

Type III tympanoplasty is indicated when both malleus and incus are absent. In this case, the graft is placed directly over the stapes head.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Wullstein classified tympanoplasty into 5 types based on the status of the ossicular chain and the placement of the graft:

 

Option A. Type I: This is simple myringoplasty done when there is only tympanic membrane perforation with intact ossicular chain. Graft is placed over the remnant tympanic membrane after inspecting the middle ear.

 

Option C. Type III: This is the correct answer. It is indicated when both malleus and incus are absent. In this case, the graft is placed directly over the stapes head.

 

Option D. Type IV: This is done when only the footplate of stapes is present. Graft is placed between oval window and round window to preserve sound transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Type III tympanoplasty (Wullstein classification), when malleus and incus are absent, the graft is placed directly over the stapes head.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 30

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss with central perforation
Intermittent ear discharge responding to antibiotics
Persistent foul-smelling, blood-stained discharge with severe nocturnal pain in a 55-year-old
History of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections

questions.text: Which of the following features is most suggestive of primary carcinoma of the middle ear rather than simple chronic suppurative otitis media?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Persistent foul-smelling, blood-stained discharge with severe nocturnal pain in a 55-year-old

 

This is the hallmark scenario suggestive of carcinoma of the middle ear, particularly in the 40–60 years age group. Other red flags include facial palsy, friable granulations, and progressive hearing loss or vertigo.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conductive hearing loss with central perforation: This is typical of simple chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), not necessarily carcinoma. It lacks red flags like facial palsy or blood-stained discharge.

 

Option B. Intermittent ear discharge responding to antibiotics: This suggests infective pathology, most consistent with CSOM or otitis externa, not malignancy, especially if discharge improves with conservative treatment.

 

Option D. History of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections: This is a predisposing factor for otitis media, especially in children, and has no strong association with middle ear malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carcinoma of the middle ear should be suspected in adults aged 40–60 with persistent blood-stained discharge, severe nocturnal pain, facial palsy, or granulations not responding to routine treatment.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 111

choices.text: Meningitis
Brain Abscess
Epidural Abscess
Subdural Empyema

questions.text: A patient with a long-standing history of Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM) develops neurological symptoms. Which of the following is the most common intracranial complication associated with CSOM?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meningitis

 

Option A. Meningitis is the most common intracranial complication of Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM). The infection can spread to the meninges, leading to inflammation and the characteristic symptoms of meningitis, including headache, fever, neck stiffness, and altered mental status.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. A brain abscess is a serious complication of CSOM, but it is less common than meningitis. It typically presents with localized neurological symptoms depending on the area of the brain affected, along with signs of increased intracranial pressure.

 

Option C. An epidural abscess is a collection of pus between the dura mater and the skull. While it can occur as a complication of CSOM, it is less common compared to meningitis.

 

Option D. Subdural empyema, a collection of pus between the dura mater and the arachnoid membrane, is a rare but serious complication of CSOM. However, meningitis remains the more common intracranial complication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meningitis is the most common intracranial complication of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), characterized by the spread of infection to the meninges leading to inflammation and associated neurological symptoms.

 

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 75-85

choices.text: It clearly demonstrates attic, aditus, and antrum
The sagittal plane of the skull is perpendicular to the film
It shows external auditory canal superimposed on the internal auditory canal
The X-ray beam is projected at a 45° caudocranial angle

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Law’s view (lateral oblique view) used in radiological assessment of the mastoid?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It shows external auditory canal superimposed on the internal auditory canal

 

This is a defining feature of Law’s view, which allows visualization of structures like the mastoid air cells, tegmen, TM joint, and lateral sinus plate. It helps in detecting mastoid pathology.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It clearly demonstrates attic, aditus, and antrum: Incorrect. Law’s view does not show the key area of the mastoid (attic, aditus, antrum) well. These are better visualized in Stenver’s or Owen’s view.

 

Option B. The sagittal plane of the skull is perpendicular to the film: Incorrect. In Law’s view, the sagittal plane is parallel to the film, not perpendicular.

 

Option D. The X-ray beam is projected at a 45° caudocranial angle: Incorrect. The correct angle for Law’s view is 15° cephalocaudal, not 45° or caudocranial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Law’s view (lateral oblique), the sagittal plane is parallel to the film and the X-ray beam is angled 15° cephalocaudal, showing the EAC superimposed on the IAC but not well visualizing the attic, aditus, or antrum.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 433

choices.text: It is a lateral view used to visualize mastoid air cell septations
It provides comparison of both petrous pyramids and is useful in acoustic neuroma evaluation
It is a posteroanterior projection with no angle used to visualize frontal sinuses
It does not show internal auditory canal or cochlea clearly

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Towne’s view in radiology of the temporal bone is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It provides comparison of both petrous pyramids and is useful in acoustic neuroma evaluation

 

  • Towne’s view is an anteroposterior projection with 30° cranial tilt, allowing comparison of both petrous pyramids. It helps visualize:
    • Arcuate eminence & superior semicircular canal
    • Mastoid antrum
    • Internal auditory canal (IAC)
    • Tympanic cavity
  • Cochlea
    • This view is useful in evaluating acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral view for mastoid air cell septations:  This refers to Schuller’s view, which is a lateral oblique projection for mastoid air cells and key mastoid structures—not Towne’s view.

 

Option C. Posteroanterior projection for frontal sinuses:  This describes Caldwell’s or Waters’ view, used in PNS imaging, not temporal bone or acoustic neuroma evaluation.

 

Option D. Does not show IAC or cochlea: Incorrect. Towne’s view does show the internal auditory canal and cochlea, making it useful in neuroma evaluation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Towne’s view is an AP view with 30° cranial tilt used to compare both petrous pyramids and visualize structures like the IAC and cochlea, especially useful in acoustic neuroma and petrositis assessment.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 433

choices.text: It is a lateral oblique view that best shows mastoid air cells and sinodural angle
It projects the petrous pyramid through the occiput and does not visualize the internal auditory canal
It is used for comparison of both petrous pyramids and is helpful in diagnosing acoustic neuroma
It cannot visualize the cochlea or labyrinth due to orbital interference

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Transorbital view in radiographic imaging is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is used for comparison of both petrous pyramids and is helpful in diagnosing acoustic neuroma

 

  • This is the correct answer. In the transorbital view, the occiput is placed on the film, and the orbitomeatal line is perpendicular to the film. The X-ray beam passes through the orbit, projecting the entire petrous pyramid, internal auditory canal, cochlea, and labyrinth, allowing comparison of both sides. It is useful for evaluating acoustic neuroma and petrous apex lesions.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral oblique view for mastoid air cells: This describes Schuller’s view, not the Transorbital view. Schuller’s is used to visualize the mastoid region, while transorbital view targets the petrous pyramid and IAC.

 

Option B. Projects through occiput and does not show IAC: Incorrect. In the transorbital view, the X-ray beam passes through the orbit, and it does visualize the internal auditory canal, cochlea, and labyrinth.

 

Option D. Cannot visualize cochlea or labyrinth: False. These are clearly visualized in the transorbital view, as part of the petrous pyramid contents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The transorbital view projects the petrous pyramid, IAC, cochlea, and labyrinth through the orbit and is useful for comparing both sides, especially in cases of acoustic neuroma.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 433

choices.text: It is used to remove granulation tissue from the middle ear during tympanoplasty
It is used for retracting nasal mucosa during septoplasty
It is a self-retaining retractor used to hold soft tissues apart during mastoidectomy
It is primarily used for nasal bone fracture reduction

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown and choose the correct statement regarding its use in ENT surgery:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is a self-retaining retractor used to hold soft tissues apart during mastoidectomy

 

  • The instrument shown is Mollison’s mastoid retractor. It is a self-retaining, haemostatic instrument used to retract soft tissue flaps after the postaural incision is made in mastoidectomy. It provides a clear operative field without the need for continuous manual retraction.
