Other Options:

 

Option A. Removal of granulation tissue: This is done with cup forceps or suction tips, not this instrument.

 

 

Option B. Retraction of nasal mucosa in septoplasty: Instruments like Killian’s speculum or Freer’s elevator are used for nasal mucosa retraction, not Mollison’s retractor.

 

 

Option D. Used in nasal bone fracture reduction: For nasal bone fracture reduction, Asch’s or Walsham’s forceps are used—not a retractor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mollison’s mastoid retractor is a self-retaining and haemostatic instrument used during mastoidectomy to retract soft tissues and maintain a clear surgical field.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 451

choices.text: It is used to retract the tympanomeatal flap during tympanoplasty
It is similar to a nasal speculum and is used to spread the meatus during endaural procedures
It is inserted into the middle ear cavity to aspirate fluid
It is used to excise granulations from the external auditory canal

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is Lempert’s endaural speculum. Which of the following statements is true regarding this instrument and its use?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is similar to a nasal speculum and is used to spread the meatus during endaural procedures

 

  • Lempert’s endaural speculum resembles the Vienna nasal speculum but has a curved design to match the contour of the external auditory canal. It is used to gently spread open the meatus, especially during endaural incision or while administering local anesthetic injections into the canal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Used to retract tympanomeatal flap: This is done using instruments like a flap retractor or elevators (Rosen’s or Freer’s), not a speculum.

 

Option C. Inserted into the middle ear cavity: No, this instrument is not meant for insertion into the middle ear. Suction cannulas or micro forceps are used inside the middle ear.

 

Option D. Used to excise granulations: This is done using cup forceps, not a speculum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lempert’s endaural speculum is a curved instrument used to spread the external auditory canal during endaural incisions or local injections.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 452

choices.text: Freer’s elevator – used for raising tympanomeatal flap in tympanoplasty
MacEwen’s curette and cell seeker – used in mastoid surgery to explore air cells and remove septa
Lempert’s curette – used to remove nasal polyps in outpatient setting
Mollison’s retractor – used to retract skin flaps in neck dissection

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and select the correct statement regarding its use:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MacEwen’s curette and cell seeker – used in mastoid surgery to explore air cells and remove septa

 

  • The instrument shown is MacEwen’s curette and cell seeker, which is double-ended:
    • One end is used to seek and explore mastoid air cells,
    • The other is a curette used to remove bony septa and granulation tissue during mastoidectomy.
      It is a standard tool in mastoid surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Freer’s elevator:  This instrument has a flat and rounded end used to elevate mucoperichondrial flaps in septoplasty, not for curettage or air cell exploration.

 

 

Option C. Lempert’s curette: While also used in mastoid surgery, it has a spoon-like scoop, not this dual-ended structure.

 

 

Option D. Mollison’s retractor: This is a self-retaining retractor used to retract soft tissues in mastoid or neck surgeries, not to curette bone or explore cells.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

MacEwen’s curette and cell seeker is a dual-ended instrument used in mastoid surgery to explore air cells and remove bony septa or granulations.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 452

choices.text: Invagination of pars flaccida due to eustachian tube dysfunction
Hyperplasia of basal layer of skin in the external auditory canal
Migration of squamous epithelium through a marginal perforation
Persistence of embryonic epithelial cell rests in the middle ear

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with chronic ear discharge and hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals a posterosuperior marginal perforation with granulation tissue. A diagnosis of secondary acquired cholesteatoma is made. Which of the following best describes the most likely mechanism of cholesteatoma formation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Migration of squamous epithelium through a marginal perforation

 

  • Secondary acquired cholesteatoma typically occurs in the setting of a pre-existing perforation (especially marginal), through which squamous epithelium migrates into the middle ear. This is the most accepted theory for this form of cholesteatoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Invagination of pars flaccida due to eustachian tube dysfunction: Describes the pathogenesis of primary acquired cholesteatoma, where pars flaccida invaginates due to negative pressure – not applicable in a case with a known perforation.

 

Option B. Hyperplasia of basal layer of skin in the external auditory canal: refers to Ruedi’s theory of basal cell hyperplasia, but it is less commonly accepted and not specific to secondary cholesteatoma.

 

Option D. Persistence of embryonic epithelial cell rests in the middle ear:  Describes the origin of congenital cholesteatoma, not secondary acquired.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary acquired cholesteatoma arises most commonly from epithelial migration through a pre-existing marginal perforation, especially in the posterosuperior quadrant.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 67

choices.text: Start topical antibiotic ear drops and discharge the patient
Prescribe oral antihistamines and nasal decongestants
Hospitalize, start systemic antibiotics, and consider myringotomy
Schedule a hearing test and review after 2 weeks

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with a 3-week history of ear discharge following acute otitis media. Examination reveals mastoid tenderness, sagging of the posterosuperior canal wall, and a dull, bulging tympanic membrane. The child also has a fever and appears toxic. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hospitalize, start systemic antibiotics, and consider myringotomy

 

  • The child shows classical features of acute mastoiditis—persistence of discharge >3 weeks, mastoid tenderness, sagging canal wall, systemic symptoms. Immediate hospitalization, IV antibiotics, and myringotomy are warranted. If not resolved, cortical mastoidectomy may be needed.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start topical antibiotic ear drops and discharge the patient: Incorrect. Topical antibiotics are insufficient in mastoiditis. This is not a simple otitis externa or minor infection.

 

Option B. Prescribe oral antihistamines and nasal decongestants: Incorrect. Antihistamines and decongestants are useful in eustachian tube dysfunction but not in acute mastoiditis with signs of systemic toxicity and complications.

 

Option D. Schedule a hearing test and review after 2 weeks: Incorrect. Delaying treatment may worsen the condition or lead to intracranial complications. Hearing tests are secondary in acute management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute mastoiditis presents with postauricular pain, discharge, mastoid tenderness, and systemic features; it requires hospitalization, IV antibiotics, and myringotomy ± mastoidectomy.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 77
questions.video_explanation_heading: ACUTE MASTOIDITIS SHOWING POSTERIOR MEATAL WALL SAGGING INTO EAC. PULSATILE NATURE OF DISCHARGE INDICATES ACTIVE DISEASE PROCESS GOING ON

choices.text: Extradural abscess
Subdural empyema
Brain abscess
Meningitis

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with a history of chronic suppurative otitis media presents with persistent headache, foul-smelling pulsatile ear discharge, and malaise. During mastoid surgery, pus is found between the bone and dura without overt meningeal signs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extradural abscess

 

  • An extradural abscess is a collection of pus between the bone and dura mater. It may be silent or present with persistent unilateral headache, low-grade fever, ear pain, and pulsatile discharge. It often arises from acute or chronic otitis media, especially with cholesteatoma. Diagnosis is confirmed during mastoidectomy or on CT/MRI. Treatment includes surgical evacuation and antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subdural empyema: Incorrect. Subdural empyema presents more dramatically with severe neurological signs such as altered sensorium, seizures, and focal deficits due to pus in the subdural space. It is a more severe and rapidly progressive condition than extradural abscess.

 

Option C. Brain abscess: Incorrect. Brain abscess causes signs of raised intracranial pressure, focal neurological signs, and is not limited to the bone-dura interface. It typically follows prolonged infection or untreated suppurative otitis media.

 

Option D. Meningitis: Incorrect. Meningitis presents with high-grade fever, neck rigidity, photophobia, and altered mental status. The absence of meningeal signs and the presence of localized pus favors extradural abscess.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extradural abscess is a localized collection of pus between bone and dura in otitis media, often discovered intraoperatively and managed by mastoidectomy and antibiotics.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 81

choices.text: High-dose systemic antibiotics for 10 days
Myringotomy with grommet insertion
Cortical mastoidectomy
Radical mastoidectomy

questions.text: A child presents with hearing loss and recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Otoscopic examination reveals a dull, retracted tympanic membrane with visible air-fluid levels and bubbles. Tympanometry shows a flat curve. What is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myringotomy with grommet insertion

 

  • The image shows classical signs of OME – retracted, dull tympanic membrane with air-fluid levels and bubbles. Treatment involves myringotomy and grommet insertion to ventilate the middle ear and drain the effusion, especially in chronic/recurrent cases or if speech is affected.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High-dose systemic antibiotics for 10 days: Incorrect. Antibiotics may help in acute otitis media, but this case is otitis media with effusion (OME), a sterile effusion with no signs of active infection, hence antibiotics alone are not appropriate.

 

Option C. Cortical mastoidectomy: Incorrect. Cortical mastoidectomy is not a first-line treatment for OME. It is reserved for complications like mastoiditis.

 

Option D. Radical mastoidectomy: Incorrect. Radical mastoidectomy is done in unsafe CSOM with cholesteatoma, not in a case of OME.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In otitis media with effusion (OME), myringotomy with grommet insertion is the treatment of choice to ventilate the middle ear and drain sterile effusion.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 65
questions.video_explanation_heading: LEFT MYRINGOTOMY WITH GROMMET INSERTION IN ANTERO-INFERIOR QUADRANT

choices.text: Diffuse suppurative labyrinthitis
True positive fistula sign
False positive fistula sign (Hennebert’s sign)
False negative fistula sign

questions.text: A patient with chronic otitis media and cholesteatoma develops vertigo when pressure is applied to the tragus. However, there is no visible evidence of a perilymph fistula. Which of the following best explains this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) False positive fistula sign (Hennebert’s sign)

 

  • This is the correct answer. Hennebert’s sign refers to a positive fistula test without a true fistula, seen in conditions like congenital syphilis (due to hypermobile stapes footplate) and late-stage Ménière’s disease (due to fibrous attachments between the footplate and membranous labyrinth).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diffuse suppurative labyrinthitis: This condition involves pus formation in the labyrinth due to extensive inner ear infection. It presents with severe vertigo, hearing loss, and nystagmus, but it is not related to pressure-induced vertigo or fistula sign testing.

 

Option B. True positive fistula sign: A true positive fistula sign occurs when there is an actual perilymph fistula, commonly due to cholesteatoma eroding the bone over the lateral semicircular canal. Applying pressure to the tragus or using Siegel’s speculum causes vertigo in such cases. However, in this question, there is no visible fistula, so it's not a true positive.

 

Option D. False negative fistula sign: This occurs when a real fistula is present but test is negative, typically seen when the labyrinth is nonfunctional (dead labyrinth) or cholesteatoma covers the fistula site, masking the pressure-induced symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:


A false positive fistula sign (Hennebert’s sign) is seen when vertigo occurs without an actual perilymph fistula, commonly in congenital syphilis and late-stage Ménière’s disease.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 56
